Dive into the diverse and captivating world of James McAvoy’s filmography with our roundup of his best movies to date. From his early beginnings to his current successes, this article will take you on a journey through the actor’s most memorable performances. As you explore the depth of McAvoy’s talent, you’ll gain a newfound appreciation for his versatility and skill on the silver screen. So, sit back, relax, and get ready to be entertained by our James McAvoy Movies roundup.

1. The Near Room (1995)

The Near Room” is a gripping drama-thriller that explores the darker side of human nature. Set in the UK, the movie follows the journey of struggling journalist, Charlie Colquhoun, as he grapples with his shattered past and present entangled in a web of corruption, murder, and child abuse.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

2. Behind the Lines (1997)

In the trenches of World War One, two of England’s most esteemed poets, Wilfred Owen and Siegfried Sassoon, face the unspeakable horrors of war in “Behind the Lines, “ released in 1998. Based on Pat Barker’s acclaimed novel, this gripping drama delves into the emotional turmoil of soldiers sent to an asylum, where trauma-induced disorders such as shell shock and PTSD wreak havoc.

📺 Watch now free with Prime

🖼️ Check out these cool movie posters & art

3. Lorna Doone (2000)

In the tumultuous year of 1685, “Lorna Doone, “ a gripping drama and romance set amidst the political and religious maelstrom, showcases a farmer’s unexpected yet forbidden love for the enchanting queen of the infamous Doone clan, a family he vowed vengeance upon. Torn between loyalty and passion, the two protagonists navigate the treacherous world of blood feuds, faith, and tradition, ultimately grappling with the perilous consequences of their ill-fated union.

4. The Pool (2001)

Dive into a chilling Horror, Mystery, and Thriller film set in an abandoned water park. The Pool, released in 2001, follows an elite group of international students attending an elite school in Prague. As they indulge in a celebration, they unknowingly cross paths with a masked killer who leaves a blood-curdling trail of stalked and murdered victims.

5. Bollywood Queen (2002)

Bollywood Queen” is a vibrant and musical romantic journey set in London’s bustling East End. It follows the love story of a British Indian girl and an aspiring artist, exploring the dynamic between cultures and identity. The film captivates audiences with its captivating melodies and heartfelt emotions.

6. Bright Young Things (2003)

In the glamorous and vibrant city of London during the 1930s, the young, wealthy, and charming set of society comes to life in the film “Bright Young Things. “ Adapted from Evelyn Waugh’s novel “Vile Bodies, “ this colorful comedy-drama offers a witty and engaging portrayal of the era’s high society and its excesses.

7. Strings (2004)

Strings” (2004) is a captivating fantasy adventure that follows Prince Adair (James McAvoy) on his quest to avenge his father’s supposed murder. However, as he embarks on his journey, he soon discovers a shocking truth: his father didn’t die, but committed suicide instead. To make matters more complex, the warrior woman he encounters reveals the harsh truth about his people and their troubled history.

8. Rory O’Shea Was Here (2004)

Rory O’Shea Was Here” is a heartwarming and funny film about the unbreakable bond between two unlikely friends. It’s a tale of friendship, acceptance, and human connection that transcends disabilities. When kinetic Rory, played by James McAvoy, moves into Carrigmore Residential Home for the Disabled, he sparks a revolution. His most significant impact is on Michael, a young man with cerebral palsy and unintelligible speech. Somehow, Rory manages to understand Michael and encourages him to experience life beyond the confines of his home.

9. Wimbledon (2004)

Wimbledon” is a heartwarming, lighthearted romantic comedy-drama directed by Richard Loncraine. Starring Kirsten Dunst and Paul Bettany, it tells the story of a once-successful tennis player who has lost his ambition, plummeting to the 119th ranking. However, when he meets a talented young woman on the women’s circuit, his focus is revitalized, and he is inspired to aim for the coveted Wimbledon title.

10. The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (2005)

Experience the magic of Narnia in The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, a captivating adventure that takes you to a realm filled with wonder. Lucy and her siblings stumble upon a mysterious wardrobe and find themselves transported to the mystical world of Narnia. As fate brings them together with the powerful lion Aslan, they must unite to defeat the wicked White Witch.

11. The 78th Annual Academy Awards (2006)

Get ready for an unforgettable night of glamour, drama, and high stakes as you join host Jon Stewart for the 78th Annual Academy Awards! . This star-studded ceremony, broadcast in March of 2006, celebrates the year’s most iconic films, including “Brokeback Mountain, “ “Capote, “ “Crash, “ “Good Night, and Good Luck, “ and “Munich. “ As you tune in to witness the magic unfold, prepare yourselves for an evening filled with captivating performances, unexpected surprises, and an awe-inspiring tribute to the timeless power of cinema.

12. Starter for 10 (2006)

Starter for 10 is a captivating comedy-drama that follows Brian Jackson, a working-class student in 1985, as he embarks on his first year at prestigious Bristol University. As he navigates the challenges of academia, friendship, and romance, Brian finds himself drawn into an unexpected world of voyeurism and intrigue.

13. The Last King of Scotland (2006)

The Last King of Scotland is a riveting drama centered around the brutal regime of Ugandan dictator Idi Amin as experienced by his personal physician. Set in the 1970s, viewers are transported into the tumultuous world of Amin’s reign, with the unforgettable portrayal of the dictator by Forest Whitaker earning him an Oscar nomination. Alongside a compelling lead role from James McAvoy, the film also stars notable actresses Gillian Anderson and Kerry Condon.

14. Penelope (2006)

Penelope” is a whimsical romantic comedy that follows the journey of a young aristocratic heiress born under a mysterious curse. The spell can only be broken when she finds love with someone who accepts her for who she is, flaws and all. Filled with vibrant characters, witty humor, and heartwarming moments, this modern fairytale takes audiences on a delightful journey of self-discovery and true love.

15. Becoming Jane (2007)

Becoming Jane is a captivating biographical drama that transports viewers to the world of Jane Austen, before she became the renowned author of beloved novels like Pride and Prejudice. Set in the 18th century, the film delves into Jane’s formative years, her passion for literature, and her ill-fated love affair with a young Irishman named Tom Lefroy.

16. Atonement (2007)

Based on the award-winning novel by Ian McEwan, “Atonement” (2007) follows the life-altering consequences of a young girl’s actions. Thirteen-year-old Briony Tallis, a budding writer, wrongly accuses her sister’s lover of a horrendous crime, setting off a series of events that forever change the course of their lives. The movie unfolds against the backdrop of World War Two, with each character navigating the complexities of love, guilt, and redemption.

Empire Movie Awards 2008, “ also known as the television special “Empire Movie Awards, “ is a must-watch event that showcases the best of the film industry. Wanted” is a thrilling 2008 action-packed movie that follows the story of a downtrodden office worker who uncovers the shocking truth about his birth. Discovering that he is the son of a skilled assassin, our protagonist also learns to share his father’s extraordinary abilities. Dive into the glamorous world of the Academy Awards as the event unfolds, offering viewers a rare glimpse into the behind-the-scenes action and unforgettable moments that make Hollywood’s biggest night truly special.

22. The Last Station (2009)

The Last Station” is a riveting historical drama that explores the complex life of Russian author Leo Tolstoy (portrayed by Christopher Plummer) as he navigates the tumultuous balance between fame and fortune, and his unwavering dedication to a life devoid of material possession. Tolstoy’s journey takes on a new dimension when he finds himself drawn into a passionate affair with a young woman, which tests the boundaries of his spiritual convictions and societal expectations. The film is further enriched by the performances of Helen Mirren and James McAvoy, and the masterful direction of Michael Hoffman.

The Conspirator, a riveting drama set in the aftermath of Abraham Lincoln’s assassination, tells the captivating story of Mary Surratt, the only woman accused as a co-conspirator in the infamous trial. As the nation rallies against her, Mary’s fate depends on her reluctant lawyer to unveil the truth and clear her name.

Arthur Christmas” is a delightful 2011 animation that puts a whimsical spin on the classic Christmas tale. Directed by Sarah Smith and Barry Cook, and starring illustrious actors like James McAvoy, Jim Broadbent, and Bill Nighy, the film follows Santa’s bumbling son, Arthur, who sets out on a mission alongside Grandsanta.

Dark Phoenix is a gripping, action-packed film that delves into the depths of human nature and the consequences of unchecked power. The story revolves around Jean Grey, an X-Men member, as she starts to develop extraordinary abilities that quickly turn her into the Dark Phoenix.
